Award.AwardTitle: Thermochemistry of Metal-Ligand Bonds (Singly and Multiply Charged) and Protonated Peptides
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms A (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Peter B. Armentrout of the Department of Chemistry of the University of Utah and graduate student researchers are studying the reactivity of electrically-charged species (ions) with neutral molecules. The chemical systems being studied include transistion metal ions such as zinc (Zn2+), cadmium (Cd2+) and tungsten (W+), and biologically relevant molecules such as the amino acids asparagine, glycine and glutamine. From these experiments, they obtain information about the changes in energy between reactant and product molecules(thermochemistry) as well as information about the speed with which these reactions take place (kinetics). Such quantitative information is of use to a broad range of scientific endeavors. Professor Armentrout has made an evolving data analysis program (CRUNCH), freely available to groups worldwide. This program enhances infrastructure for research. This project involves many students(undergraduate and graduate) in all aspects of research. Students design and construct instrumentation, interface data acquisition equipment, propose and conduct experiments, run computational studies, analyze experimental and theoretical results, and prepare manuscripts. Opportunities to conduct research at a user facility in the Netherlands broaden the students' research and cultural experience further. Outreach efforts by the Professor Armentrout include participation in the STEM for U Week in which he visits several K-12 classes to present scientific content and career possibilities.

Prof. Armentrout and his graduate students carry out a series of experiments, exploring the reactivity of cations with neutral reaction partners, using their guided ion beam tandem mass spectrometer (GIBMS) instruments. Studies include: (1) electronic state-specific measurements of transition metal cation reactivity, with an emphasis on quantitative evaluation of spin-orbit effects on chemical reactivity; (2) measurements of solvation energies of multiply charged metal ions, including explicit quantification of the potential energy surface for charge separation channels, emphasizing environmentally and biologically important examples; (3) binding studies of biologically-relevant molecules to metal cations and protonated systems, with an emphasis on deamidation of asparagine (believed to be a major molecular process in aging); (4) spectroscopic studies of species formed in carbon-hydrogen bond activation reactions by transition metal cations and of metallated biologically relevant molecules; and (5) theoretical work to complement all of the experimental studies in (1) - (4). The research is interdisciplinary, utilizing state-of-the-art physical and analytical methods. Students receiving training in Professor Armentrout's laboratory have gone on to positions in academia and industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcomes for National Science Foundation Grant CHE-1664618

In this project funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division of the NSF, Professor Peter B. Armentrout and his students at the University of Utah have performed research that has been disseminated in 26 published papers and 31 invited seminars or contributed talks. Their work explores the structure and reactivity of various molecules in the gas-phase, including metal cations (“cation” means positively charged) and complexes composed of metal cations and other molecules such as water (H2O), methane (CH4), and biologically relevant amino acids and peptides. These studies are conducted in the gas phase because it is important to understand the inherent structure and properties of these molecular systems, in other words, in the absence of the countless water molecules they would encounter in an aqueous solution. The Armentrout research group is developing new techniques to deliver charged molecules and complexes into the gas phase, either free of water or with a selected number of water molecules or other organic solvent molecules. The research includes four main thrusts: What is the intrinsic reactivity of various metals? How strongly bound are solvent molecules to metals? How do the properties of a molecular ion change when it is excited by laser light or collisions? How do ionized peptides decompose, and what are the molecular structures of decomposition products? Such information is valuable in developing new catalytic systems, in understanding biological function (including effects on health), and in environmental remediation efforts. In all cases, these experimental studies are complemented by theoretical examinations of the same phenomena.

For transition metal cations, the oxidation of atomic rhenium and osmium cations by sulfur dioxide were examined with energetics measured for generation of the metal monoxide, dioxide, monosulfide, and oxysulfide cations. Measurements of hydration energies included cobalt dications (Co2+) with four to eleven water ligands and iron hydroxide cations (FeOH+) with two to nine water ligands.

Research activity regarding biological molecules included examinations of the energetics for dissociation of several dipeptides containing asparagine, which is known to undergo deamidation (loss of ammonia), a process that has been linked to aging and the onset of degenerative diseases. Energetics for fragmentation of the GAG tripeptide for comparison with previous work on GGG were examined, along with binding energies of alkali cations to lysine.

These traditional collisional and reaction studies were complemented by using infrared multiple photon dissociation (IRMPD) action spectroscopy at the Free Electron Lasers for Infrared eXperiments (FELIX) facility, Radboud University, Nijmegen, The Netherlands. For transition metals, IRMPD was used to characterize species formed in CH bond activation reactions of methane with atomic third-row transition metal cations. In addition, the structures of several complexes formed by sequential reactions of atomic iridium cations with three to four molecules of methane as well as cyclic metallocycle species formed by reactions of atomic tantalum and tantalum oxide cations with ethene were identified using IRMPD. In a study that overlaps transition metal and biological chemistry, amino acid complexes of Zn2+ and Cd2+ were examined with the idea of providing fundamental structural information regarding why Zn binds preferentially to cysteine (Cys) and histidine (His) residues in biological systems and how the toxic Cd metal replaces it. IRMPD results for complexes of these metals to aspartic acid (Asp), arginine (Arg), lysine (Lys), and methionine (Met) were published. In general, Zn forms complexes in which the amino acid is deprotonated, whereas Cd forms complexes of the intact amino acid with CdCl+. In most cases, the metal binds to the amine and carbonyl groups of the backbone and the side-chain functional group; however, for Zn(Asp-H)+, the complex undergoes rearrangement by deaminating, to form a four-coordinate species with ammonia as one ligand.

In miscellaneous work, thermodynamic studies of the benzhydrylpyridinium cations, a new class of “thermometer” ions, were performed and provide direct thermodynamic information that extends the range of the thermometer to lower values. In addition, the dissociation behavior of protonated hydrazine and azobenzene were elucidated, with the former species showing some interesting orbital conservation phenomena that had not previously been characterized.

In nearly all of these projects, graduate and undergraduate students participated in all phases of the research experience by acquiring the data, analyzing it, writing it up for publication, and often presenting results orally or via posters at conferences. The theoretical studies that often accompany the experimental work are also carried out by the students in most cases. Students engaged in this research project are gaining valuable experience in state-of-the-art physical and analytical methods, including a technique called guided ion beam tandem mass spectrometry, and quantum mechanical calculations. Several students engaged in international research by traveling to the Netherlands. During the course of this grant, two students completed their Ph.D. theses while supported by the National Science Foundation.

 


Last Modified: 08/05/2020
Modified by: Peter B Armentrout
